Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Broad dissatisfaction with the current tipping culture, especially the sense of coercion from tablet prompts and requests in low- or no-service contexts (e.g., counter pickup). Many feel tipping has become over-expected and uncomfortable.
  • Strong support for shifting responsibility to employers: require a livable base wage (at least minimum wage for tipped workers) so income doesn’t depend on tips. Several favor moving toward a European-style model where service is included in prices.
  • Many want tipping to be optional and performance-based: tip more for good or exceptional service, less or none for poor service, and only after services are rendered—not beforehand.
  • Reform ideas include: replacing tipping with an automatic service charge (often modest) while keeping discretionary tipping optional; integrating service costs into menu prices; standardizing clearer, non-manipulative tipping guidelines; and limiting tip prompts to roles providing clear service.
  • Point-of-sale changes suggested: make “no tip” easy to find, avoid high default percentages, and don’t prompt for tipping in situations with minimal service.
  • A smaller set supports maintaining or even increasing tipping (e.g., fixed-amount tips instead of percentages, always tipping or overtipping), with one idea to offer acknowledgments or small incentives (thank-you notes, coupons) to recognize tips.
  • Additional notes: concerns about affordability for consumers, fairness to workers under the current system, and occasional proposals like making tips tax-free if tipping remains.

[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I believe in waiters making minimum wage if not more/proportional to the rate of inflation so there is no need for tipping. The system should be like it is in other countries where workers are paid a fair wage; it makes more sense for restaurants to charge customers what they need in order to make up for paying fair wages.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments: - Prevailing sentiment: Tipping culture—especially in the U.S.—is seen as excessive, coercive, and spreading to contexts that don’t involve meaningful service. Many feel pressured by tablet prompts and pre-service tip requests. - Compensation view: Broad agreement that employers should pay a fair, livable wage (ending the sub-minimum “tipped wage”), with tips treated as an optional bonus for good or exceptional service. Several would accept higher menu prices to fund wages. - System reform ideas: - Abolish tipping entirely and fold compensation into prices or a built-in service charge (often cited around 10%). - Keep tipping but make it clearly voluntary, merit-based, and limited mainly to full-service restaurants—not pickup, fast food, or coffee counters. - Standardize aspects (e.g., fixed tip amounts for small bills, clear guidelines by service level) or consider mandatory tips only if wages aren’t livable. - Practical improvements: Show an easy “no tip” option, prompt only after service is delivered, and avoid aggressive default tip screens. Limit who is prompted for tips to roles providing direct service. - Minority perspectives: Some strongly defend tipping as an incentive and tip generously; a few suggest mandatory tipping or argue customers shouldn’t use tipped services if they can’t tip. Other niche suggestions include not taxing tips and offering small thank-you tokens or coupons in return. - Context: Several point to European/Japanese models—higher wages or automatic service charges with minimal tipping—as preferable.
